title: Isaiah Chapter 9 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 9 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 9 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 9.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 9:6, what name is NOT given to the child born unto us?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:6 lists the names as Wonderful, Counsellor, The mighty God, The everlasting Father, The Prince of Peace; 'The Mighty Warrior' is not mentioned.

questions.question: Which lands are mentioned in Isaiah 9:1 as being afflicted?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:1 specifically mentions the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali as being afflicted.

questions.question: What is described as 'the light' in Isaiah 9:2?
options: A great light seen by those in darkness
questions.correctAnswer: A great light seen by those in darkness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:2 states that the people who walked in darkness have seen a great light, meaning a spiritual or divine light.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 9:4, what has God broken for the people?
options: The yoke of his burden and the rod of his oppressor
questions.correctAnswer: The yoke of his burden and the rod of his oppressor
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:4 explicitly mentions God breaking the yoke of burden and the rod of oppressor, symbolizing liberation.

questions.question: What will be upon the child's shoulder according to Isaiah 9:6?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:6 says 'and the government shall be upon his shoulder,' indicating authority and rule.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 9:7 states that the increase of his government and peace will have no end.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:7 clearly states that the increase of his government and peace shall have no end.

questions.question: In Isaiah 9:10, what do the people say about the fallen bricks?
options: We will build with hewn stones
questions.correctAnswer: We will build with hewn stones
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:10 records the people saying, 'The bricks are fallen down, but we will build with hewn stones.'

questions.question: Who are set as adversaries against Israel according to Isaiah 9:11?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:11 states the LORD will set up the adversaries of Rezin against Israel.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 9:14, what will the LORD cut off from Israel?
options: Head and tail, branch and rush
questions.correctAnswer: Head and tail, branch and rush
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:14 states the LORD will cut off from Israel head and tail, branch and rush, in one day.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 9:17 says the Lord will have mercy on orphans and widows.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:17 states the Lord shall have no mercy on orphans and widows because of the people's hypocrisy and evil.

questions.question: What will happen to the people as described in Isaiah 9:20?
options: They shall eat the flesh of their own arms
They shall be saved from hunger
They shall share food with neighbors
questions.correctAnswer: They shall eat the flesh of their own arms
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:20 describes a dire situation where people will eat the flesh of their own arms due to hunger and desperation.

questions.question: Who are said to be against Judah in Isaiah 9:21?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:21 states that Manasseh and Ephraim together shall be against Judah.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 9:13 says the people turn to God after being smitten.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:13 states that the people do not turn unto him that smiteth them nor seek the LORD of hosts.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Isaiah 9:6: 'For unto us a child is born, unto us a son is ______.'
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:6 says, 'unto us a son is given,' indicating the gift of a son to the people.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 9:18 compare wickedness to?
options: Fire that devours briers and thorns
A flood that covers the land
A lion that roars in the forest
questions.correctAnswer: Fire that devours briers and thorns
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:18 states wickedness burns as fire and devours briers and thorns.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 9 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 9 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Isaiah 9, what biblical truth would you share about God's promise in times of darkness?
options: The people walking in darkness have seen a great light
God will abandon those in darkness
No light will shine on those in trouble
questions.correctAnswer: The people walking in darkness have seen a great light
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:2 says, 'The people that walked in darkness have seen a great light,' promising hope and divine presence in trials. This is supported by the assurance of God's ongoing commitment in verses 7 and 19.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 9:6 teach us about the nature of Christ and His role in our lives?
options: He is called Wonderful, Counsellor, The mighty God, The everlasting Father, The Prince of Peace
He is only a prophet with no authority
He brings only earthly power and wealth
He is a temporary king with limited reign
questions.correctAnswer: He is called Wonderful, Counsellor, The mighty God, The everlasting Father, The Prince of Peace
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:6 describes the Messiah with divine titles emphasizing His wisdom, power, eternal nature, and peace-giving role, highlighting His comprehensive lordship and guidance for believers (also see verses 7 and 4).

questions.question: A believer feels burdened by oppression and hardship. According to Isaiah 9, what encouragement regarding God's deliverance can you offer?
options: God has broken the yoke of his burden and the rod of his oppressor
Oppression will never end for God's people
Believers must fight their oppressors by force alone
God ignores the suffering of His people
questions.correctAnswer: God has broken the yoke of his burden and the rod of his oppressor
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:4 speaks of God breaking the yoke and rod of oppression as in the day of Midian, assuring believers of divine intervention and relief from hardship (see also verses 1 and 7).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 9:7 encourage believers in their faith regarding God's kingdom?
options: The increase of his government and peace shall have no end
God's kingdom will be temporary and weak
Believers must create their own peace without God
Justice and judgment will be absent in God's reign
questions.correctAnswer: The increase of his government and peace shall have no end
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:7 assures believers that God's kingdom is eternal, established with justice and judgment, providing hope and stability in faith (supported by verses 6 and 19).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with pride and self-reliance instead of trusting God. What warning from Isaiah 9 can you share?
options: The bricks are fallen down, but we will build with hewn stones
Pride is the foundation of God's kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: The bricks are fallen down, but we will build with hewn stones
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:10 highlights the pride and stubbornness of Israel in rebuilding with stronger materials rather than humbling themselves before God, warning believers against self-reliance and pride (see also verses 9 and 13).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 9:13-14, what is the consequence of turning away from God and not seeking Him?
options: The LORD will cut off from Israel head and tail, branch and rush
They will find peace without God
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will cut off from Israel head and tail, branch and rush
questions.explanation: Verses 13 and 14 explain that Israel's refusal to seek God results in severe judgment, symbolized by cutting off leaders and followers alike, emphasizing the seriousness of disobedience.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 9:17 describe the behavior of people who face God's judgment, and what lesson can believers learn?
options: Every one is a hypocrite and an evildoer, and every mouth speaketh folly
People become more faithful and humble
Judgment brings out the best in everyone
All will repent and seek God immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Every one is a hypocrite and an evildoer, and every mouth speaketh folly
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:17 reveals the hypocrisy and evil that provoke God's anger, warning believers to maintain integrity, humility, and obedience to avoid such judgment (see also verses 13 and 19).

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 9 teaches that God's anger will eventually be turned away from the people despite their stubbornness.
questions.explanation: Repeatedly in Isaiah 9 (verses 12, 17, 19, 21), it is emphasized that God's anger is not turned away, and His hand is stretched out still, showing persistent judgment due to disobedience.

questions.question: In the context of Isaiah 9, how can believers understand the phrase 'the government shall be upon his shoulder' regarding Christ's leadership?
options: Christ carries the responsibility of ruling and guiding His people
Christ has no role in earthly governance
The government belongs only to human kings
Christ's leadership is temporary and weak
questions.correctAnswer: Christ carries the responsibility of ruling and guiding His people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:6 speaks of the Messiah's government resting on His shoulder, symbolizing His authority and care in leadership, offering believers confidence in His divine guidance (see verses 7 and 4).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with forgiveness and reconciliation. Based on Isaiah 9:6-7, what biblical truth about peace would you share?
options: The Prince of Peace will establish an unending kingdom of peace and justice
Forgiveness is not necessary for peace
Peace comes only from human effort
questions.correctAnswer: The Prince of Peace will establish an unending kingdom of peace and justice
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:6-7 introduces the Messiah as the Prince of Peace who brings eternal peace and justice, encouraging believers to pursue reconciliation and trust in God's peace.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 9 teaches that God's zeal ensures the establishment and continuation of His kingdom forever.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:7 states that 'The zeal of the LORD of hosts will perform this,' affirming God's passionate commitment to establishing His eternal kingdom.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 9:18 use imagery to describe the consequences of wickedness, and what practical lesson does it teach believers?
options: Wickedness burns like fire, devouring and spreading rapidly
questions.correctAnswer: Wickedness burns like fire, devouring and spreading rapidly
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:18 compares wickedness to a consuming fire that spreads quickly, reminding believers of the destructive power of sin and the importance of living righteously.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by conflict within the church family. Based on Isaiah 9:20-21, what biblical insight can you offer about division and self-destructive behavior?
options: They shall eat every man the flesh of his own arm, indicating self-destructive conflict
Division is a sign of God's favor
questions.correctAnswer: They shall eat every man the flesh of his own arm, indicating self-destructive conflict
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:20 describes a grim picture of self-destructive strife, warning believers about the dangers of internal division and the need for unity and love (also see verse 21).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 9:6 states, 'For unto us a child is born, unto us a son is given: and the government shall be upon his shoulder: and his name shall be called _______, Counsellor, The mighty God, The everlasting Father, The Prince of Peace.'
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:6 lists the names of the Messiah, beginning with 'Wonderful,' emphasizing His miraculous nature and divine role, which encourages trust and faith.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 9:3, how does God bring joy to His people despite their troubles?
options: They rejoice before God as men rejoice in harvest and dividing spoil
God does not care about joy
Joy comes only from earthly success
questions.correctAnswer: They rejoice before God as men rejoice in harvest and dividing spoil
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:3 uses the imagery of harvest joy to illustrate God's gift of joy to His people, encouraging believers to find joy in God's provision even in trials (see verses 2 and 4).

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 9 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 9.

questions.question: Which geographical regions are mentioned in Isaiah 9:1 as having been afflicted by God?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:1 explicitly mentions the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali as regions lightly afflicted initially and then grievously afflicted afterward.

questions.question: In Isaiah 9:2, what metaphor is used to describe the transformation experienced by the people?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:2 uses the imagery of people walking in darkness seeing a great light to indicate transformation from despair to hope.

questions.question: Isaiah 9:6 lists several titles for the child born. Which of the following is NOT one of those titles?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:6 names the child Wonderful, Counsellor, The mighty God, The everlasting Father, and The Prince of Peace, but does not use 'Son of Man' which is a New Testament title.

questions.question: What is promised about the government and peace of the child mentioned in Isaiah 9:7?
options: It will last for forty years
It will be limited to Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:7 states that the increase of his government and peace shall have no end, emphasizing eternal reign.

questions.question: Who is referred to as the 'head' in the judgment pronounced in Isaiah 9:15?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:15 identifies the ancient and honourable as the head, contrasting with the prophet teaching lies as the tail.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 9:10, what attitude do the people express in response to destruction?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:10 shows the people responding defiantly to fallen bricks by planning to build with hewn stones and to replace sycamores with cedars.

questions.question: Isaiah 9:4 compares God’s deliverance to which historical event?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:4 references the day of Midian when God broke the yoke of burden and the rod of the oppressor, symbolizing deliverance.

questions.question: Which two nations are described as adversaries against Israel in Isaiah 9:11-12?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:11-12 explicitly mentions the Syrians before and the Philistines behind as enemies devouring Israel.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 9:6 foretells the birth of a child who will be called 'The everlasting Father.'
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:6 lists 'The everlasting Father' as one of the names given to the child born unto us.

questions.question: What literary device is predominantly used in Isaiah 9:6 when listing the titles of the child?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:6 uses parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, by listing multiple names that emphasize the child’s attributes.

questions.question: In Isaiah 9:20, what horrifying imagery is used to depict the desperation among the people?
options: Eating the flesh of their own arms
questions.correctAnswer: Eating the flesh of their own arms
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:20 describes people eating the flesh of their own arms, symbolizing extreme famine and desperation.

questions.question: Which phrase in Isaiah 9:2 connects the theme of light with deliverance from death?
options: Land of the shadow of death
questions.correctAnswer: Land of the shadow of death
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:2 mentions the 'land of the shadow of death' upon which the light shines, symbolizing deliverance from darkness and death.

questions.question: Who is responsible for the judgment and establishment of the eternal kingdom described in Isaiah 9:7?
options: The zeal of the LORD of hosts
questions.correctAnswer: The zeal of the LORD of hosts
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:7 concludes that the zeal of the LORD of hosts will perform the establishment of the eternal kingdom.

questions.question: Isaiah 9:14-15 uses a metaphor involving 'head and tail.' What does the 'tail' symbolize?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:15 identifies the tail as the prophet who teaches lies, contrasting with the head representing the ancient and honourable.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 9:18-19, what is the consequence of wickedness burning like fire?
options: It devours briers and thorns and darkens the land
questions.correctAnswer: It devours briers and thorns and darkens the land
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:18-19 depicts wickedness as a consuming fire that devours vegetation and darkens the land, symbolizing judgment.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 9 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 9 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 9:6, which of the following titles is NOT given to the child who is born?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:6 lists the titles given to the child as Wonderful, Counsellor, The mighty God, The everlasting Father, and The Prince of Peace. 'King of Kings' is a New Testament title (1 Timothy 6:15) but is not listed here.

questions.question: What does the government rest upon according to Isaiah 9:6?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:6 says 'the government shall be upon his shoulder,' signifying the authority and responsibility resting on the Messiah. This connects to His kingly rule (Isaiah 22:21; Matthew 11:28-30).

questions.question: Isaiah 9:7 speaks of the increase of whose government and peace that shall have no end?
options: The government of the child born
questions.correctAnswer: The government of the child born
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:7 states that the increase of 'his' government and peace shall have no end, referring to the child born in verse 6, a Messianic prophecy fulfilled in Christ (Luke 1:32-33; Revelation 11:15).

questions.question: Which two lands are mentioned in Isaiah 9:1 as being lightly afflicted in the past?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:1 references the lands of Zebulun and Naphtali as initially lightly afflicted, indicating the historical judgment and later restoration (Matthew 4:13-16).

questions.question: Isaiah 9:2 describes the people who "walked in darkness" as having seen what?
questions.explanation: The people walking in darkness see 'a great light' shining upon them (Isaiah 9:2), a Messianic image fulfilled in Jesus as the Light of the world (John 8:12; John 1:4-9).

questions.question: What is described as being broken in Isaiah 9:4?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:4 declares that God has broken 'the yoke of his burden, and the staff of his shoulder, the rod of his oppressor,' signifying deliverance and salvation (Exodus 6:6; Matthew 11:28-30).

questions.question: Isaiah 9:10 shows the people’s response to destruction by stating they will build with what?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:10 records the prideful declaration to rebuild with hewn stones after bricks have fallen, reflecting human arrogance and rejection of divine judgment (Jeremiah 7:4; Proverbs 16:18).

questions.question: In Isaiah 9:14, the LORD says He will cut off from Israel which parts in one day?
options: Head and tail, branch and rush
Arm and leg, heart and soul
King and priest, prophet and judge
Rich and poor, young and old
questions.correctAnswer: Head and tail, branch and rush
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:14 states that the LORD will cut off 'head and tail, branch and rush' in one day, symbolizing total judgment on leadership and people (Isaiah 10:18; Ezekiel 9:8).

questions.question: Who is described as the 'head' in Isaiah 9:15?
options: The priest of the Most High
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:15 identifies 'the ancient and honourable' as the head, contrasting with the prophet of lies as the tail, emphasizing corrupt leadership (Jeremiah 23:16; Ezekiel 22:26).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 9:16, what is the effect of the leaders causing people to err?
options: They that are led are destroyed
questions.correctAnswer: They that are led are destroyed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:16 states that because leaders cause error, those led by them face destruction, highlighting the consequences of ungodly leadership (Hosea 4:6; Romans 16:17-18).

questions.question: Isaiah 9:17 describes the people as hypocrites and evildoers who speak what?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:17 says every mouth speaks folly, indicating moral and spiritual corruption that provokes God's anger (Psalm 12:2-4; Proverbs 14:9).

questions.question: What imagery does Isaiah 9:18 use to describe the burning of wickedness?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:18 uses the image of fire consuming briers and thorns, symbolizing the consuming judgment of God on sin (Hebrews 12:29; Nahum 1:6).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 9:19, what will happen to the people under the wrath of the LORD of hosts?
options: They will be as fuel of the fire
They will be sheltered and safe
They will be healed and restored
questions.correctAnswer: They will be as fuel of the fire
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:19 says the land is darkened and the people become fuel for the fire of God's wrath, depicting total destruction due to sin (Revelation 20:9; Ezekiel 22:31).

questions.question: What disturbing behavior is described in Isaiah 9:20 during the judgment?
options: Eating the flesh of their own arms
questions.correctAnswer: Eating the flesh of their own arms
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:20 graphically describes people eating the flesh of their own arms in desperation during judgment, illustrating extreme famine and chaos (Leviticus 26:29; Lamentations 4:10).

questions.question: In Isaiah 9:21, which two groups are described as being against Judah together?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 9:21 states 'Manasseh, Ephraim; and Ephraim, Manasseh: and they together shall be against Judah,' highlighting internal strife among Israel’s tribes (1 Kings 12:20; Hosea 5:5).
